Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Situation2: They identify a malfunctioning pool filtration system that could endanger swimmers’ safety if not repaired immediately.
Story: I glanced at the clock on the pool wall—6:58 p.m. My shift as a lifeguard was almost over, but I still had to check the equipment before leaving. As I walked past the filtration system, I noticed a strange noise and a blinking red light. My heart sank. If the filter wasn’t fixed, the water could become unsafe for swimmers tomorrow. I knew I should call maintenance right away and stay until someone arrived. But then my phone buzzed in my pocket. It was 7:00 p.m.—the time I always called my parents. Every week, without fail, I updated them on my life and asked about theirs. They worried if I was even a few minutes late, and I didn’t want to let them down. I stood there, torn between my responsibility to keep the pool safe and my promise to my parents. My hand hovered over my phone, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me, unsure which expectation I should meet first.
